Award.AwardTitle: Track 2 CS10K: Growing Computer Science Curriculum, Diversity, and Teacher Preparedness across Montana

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Montana is building a collaborative effort involving three major state universities and a tribal college. Its two main goals are to prepare high school teachers to teach new computer science (CS) courses in a manner that is sustainable over the long-term, and to expand CS curriculum in Montana's high schools with a special focus on improving the diversity of students who engage in CS. This project represents the first of its kind in the state of Montana due to its scope, the partnerships involved, and the potential to expand the number of students introduced to a wide variety of CS topics at an earlier age. The end result promises to be a broader population of high school students who engage with CS, who go on to major in a computing field, and who ultimately land in successful, high-paying and fulfilling professions. This project can change the economy and the future of Montana, and prepare a more diverse group of young people to take over the next generation of computing in our country.

To expand the current offerings of CS courses in Montana high schools, this effort includes the Joy and Beauty of Computing (JBC) course developed and piloted at Montana State University and rolled out to Bozeman High School, and a second CS Principles course. Activities shown to improve diversity (mentoring, pair programming, role models, etc.) will be integrated into course offerings, dual credit opportunities will be available for students, and high school teachers will participate in team-teaching arrangements and on-going professional development (PD) workshops. The educational assessment portion of the project centers on the high-level question: Does the two-course CS curriculum broaden interest and participation in high school CS career pathways? A set of sub-questions that focus separately on student participation and teacher participation will guide the data collection and analysis portion of this study. Six critical measures will be used: pre/post surveys, interviews, CS course enrollment data, artifact reviews, classroom observations, and case study. Formative and summative summaries will be provided each year by Cedar Lake Research Group to inform the research.

ProgramReference.Text: Computer Science for All (CS for All)
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broader impacts of this award include the development of professional development opportunities and resources that allowed us to train numerous high school teachers from around the state of Montana. We offered weeklong courses in the Joy and Beauty of Computing and Mobile CSP, and those teachers are now able to offer new computer sciences courses in their K12 communities. Extensive curriculum related resources were also created and made available to teachers including instructional topics/units, videos, assignments, solutions, exams, project ideas, and sample schedules. Teachers have been able to access and add to these resources during and after PD classes so that they can continue to learn and teach the materials easily in their home schools.

 

As a result of the professional development classes and resources we created through this project, hundreds of students have subsequently been able to engage in new topics of CS in their high school environments. Many of these students come from rural areas where access to computer science curriculum is limited. By providing students increased access and exposure to computer science, computational thinking, and coding, they have been able to develop interests and skills that are crucial for the current and future job market. This will, in turn, improve not only their own economic prospects, but also those of the community and state they end up working in.

 

The intellectual merit of this award includes educational research results we disseminated to the CS Education community through a number of peer-reviewed publications and presentations. These findings include a study of the effects of one of our weeklong PD classes on the programming skills of nineteen high school teachers, their confidence in programming, and their confidence for teaching programming. We have also published about the barriers that high schools face in offering more computer science courses along with tangible solutions that can help mitigate these problems. We studied the ways in which high school students are drawn into computer science and discuss the recommendations other teachers have for expanding on those efforts as well.

 

More recently, we submitted a paper (currently pending review) that presents a current snapshot of how 120 students from eight different high schools perceive computer science based on four key metrics: identity, math, teamwork and social support. Our goal was to see if perceptions in these critical areas are equalizing between males and females, and we discovered some encouraging signs that suggest advancements have been made. Lastly, another research article we submitted that is also currently pending review includes a compilation of pre and post survey responses from over 125 high school students who took one of the CS classes we trained teachers in. Our analysis describes the impact these new courses had on student interest in various CS topics and on their aspirations to continue with CS in the future. Our findings are of particular interest to educational researchers who strive to increase the reach and appeal of computer science in the high school population.

 

 


Last Modified: 11/06/2020
Modified by: Yolanda J Reimer

As a result of the professional development classes and resources we created through this project, hundreds of students have subsequently been able to engage in new topics of CS in their high school environments. By providing students increased access and exposure to computer science, computational thinking, and coding, they have been able to develop interests and skills that are crucial for the current and future job market.
